overcome. I struggled to get control of the "text" I hoped I was

> This seems to me to be the crucial point. IF you don't have side
effects and
> IF you have decoupled code then I cannot see where dependencies
between T(A)
> and T(B) make sense. A usually does not depend directly on B but on
an
> abstract interface - B just being an implementation of that
interface.

I have been sending mail and for some reason they takes hours (maybe up to a
day) to arrive, and I don't think it is my server (I have our admin check.)
Sorry, there is an explanation in the mail. ;-)

You guys all seem very caught up on decoupling, and I'll acknowledge I am
far from an OO purist, I have a job to do & I write code. I attempt to write
standalone (decoupled) classes, I attempt to make them have well structed
"APIs" but at the end of the day, if A uses B (however implemented, and
however used -- aggregation, subclassing, command/messaging paradigms,
whatever) *for whatever reason* then surely for A to work, B ought work? If
B fail a test then it has broken the contracts the tests assert, so it's
behaviours must be deemed unknown. I B is unknown, I could argue (a user
choice, on a per case basis) that it isn't worth knowing what the outcome of
A's results test are. If they pass, then perhaps those tests don't cover
enough. If they fail, isn't quite likely because B failed and what A relied
upon is bogus?

> Maybe the direct dependency on the collection object is the problem in the
> first place. You could take your problem with many test cases failing at
once
> as a strong hint to remove this direct dependency. If your collection
object,
> however, is so low level that a direct dependency does not hurt then it
> should be very very stable; the probability that it fails in a fundamental
way,
> which makes lots of other tests fail too, is very low.

There might be gold in that statement. You are saying that failures can
propagate (as I say) but that as you go up the stack the chance for
catastrophic failure ought not be there. I wonder if the result I am looking
for is better suited in the case of catastrophic failure, not just "some
obscure failure". That is possible.

With this observation, maybe what I am asking for is too fuzzy. I think that
code uses code (however you structure it) and much as there ought not be
dependency on internal, if code breaks is "API agreement" then anything that
uses that API is in doubt, and not worth testing. Trouble is, I'd not want
to do this on a "method by method" or "test by test" basics, so I was
proposing doing it on TestCases. At this level, I can see how it is not fine
grained enough, and perhaps too fuzzy.

BTW: I use junit to assert behaviours/contracts for the very reason that I
can change anything (at any level) any time. I like a good refactor that
(after a while) brings all the tests back to working. I worry t hat the
assumption of "low level stability" is counter that. It is likely right, but
it oughtn't be relied upon (IMHO).

> You haven't convinced me (yet) about two points:
> - Why is the dependency between tests a FUNDAMENTAL concept and not just
> your very personal way to sort out which test cases to run?
> - Why can't this concept be implemented without changing the core of
JUnit?

I don't think we ever gave these fair hearing because (I feel) we spent all
the time on why the idea was bad. To be frank, I didn't think anybody was
listening, and since I was struggling to make the base points I saw no
reason to try to build on the implementation issue.

I think the points (one by one) that need to get agreed or dismissed are:

1) Are test suites (as collections of tests, which have some
hierarchical/run order effect) are a "second place" to manage relationship
between testcases? Since managing in two places is always flawed, are suites
flawed? [If I refactor testcases I might forget to refactor the suites, and
that is where errors creep in.]
2) Are test suites becoming obsoleted by "brute force collectors"? How would
we know other than a user survey?
3) If "suites" have outlived their purpose, why are they the "framework" way
to manage run order?
4) Does "run order/dependency" (not side-effect dependency) have any
value -- despite it's smell?
5) Is "run order" something that ought be in the framework, however it is
implemented.

As agree w/ David, in a mail I sent yesterday but haven't seen list exploded
yet, I *may* be right about some of this, but I don't think dependency will
get an open hearing 'cos of the stench of side-effect dependency. So be it.

> But of course you're right stati8ng that many of us here are too involved
in
> JUnit and thus have a hard time giving up on "invariants" we consider to
be
> "everlasting".

Thanks for that, at least.

regards

Adam
